abstract.para: Learn the difference between &sudo; and su commands.

section.title: Introduction
section.para: You can execute single commands as a &rootuser; or another user, based on your settings in the /etc/sudoers file. The sudoers files are files that Linux administrators use to allocate system rights to the system users. This allows the administrator to control who does what. If you want to securely execute a command as a &rootuser; user, you must always use the &sudo; command. The main difference between &sudo; and su commands is that su requires the password of the target user, while &sudo; requires the password of the current user.
